title: 109_s589
content: The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays is addressed in Section 1. The "Faster FOIA Act of 2005" establishes the Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays to study methods for reducing delays in processing FOIA requests. The Commission consists of 16 members appointed by the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays consists of 16 members appointed by various entities including the House of Representatives, the Attorney General, and the Comptroller General of the United States. Members must have relevant experience. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays consists of 16 members appointed by various entities with relevant experience. Members must have experience in submitting requests under section 552 of title 5, United States Code, and in academic research related to library science, information management, or public access to Government information. The Commission will conduct a study to identify methods to reduce delays in processing requests submitted to Federal agencies under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays will conduct a study to identify methods to reduce delays in processing requests submitted to Federal agencies under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The study will also examine the system for charging fees and granting waivers of fees to reduce processing delays. A report containing the study's results, conclusions, recommendations, and legislative/administrative suggestions will be submitted to Congress and the President within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays will receive staff and administrative support services from the Comptroller General of the United States. Executive agencies, the Government Accountability Office, and the Congressional Research Service will provide necessary information to the Commission. Members will serve without compensation, and travel expenses will be covered. The Commission on Freedom of Information Act Processing Delays will receive support services from the Comptroller General of the United States. Members will be allowed travel expenses and per diem in accordance with federal rates. The Federal Advisory Committee Act will apply to the Commission, and it will terminate 30 days after submitting its report.
